div1.p: Grateful Nation Pensions Widows of Fever Martyrs

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Post; 1908
div1.p:
GRATEFUL NATION
PENSIONS WIDOWS
OF FEVER MARTYRS

Mrs. Lazear and Mrs. Carroll
Get $125 a Month Each
From Congress.

The recent action of congress granting
an increase of $125 per month to Jennie
M. Carroll, widow of Maj. James Carroll
of Maryland, and of Mabel H. Lazear,
widow of Dr. Jesse Lazear of Baltimore,
in recognition of the eminent and heroic
services of Major Carroll and Dr. Lazear,
in stamping out the yellow fever in Cuba,
is a source of particular pride and grati-
fication to James B. Lazear. second vice
president of the Central National bank
of Denver, uncle of Dr. Lazear, Major
Carroll and Dr. Lazear gave their lives
to the cause of humanity and science in
demonstrating the truth of the theory of
the transmission and propagation of yel-
low fever infection by mosquitoes.

Both of these officers were army sur-
geons who were associated with the late
Dr. Walter Reed, in whose career the
DR. JESSE LAZEAR,
Who Gave His Life in the Effort to
Stamp Out Yellow Fever in Cuba.
Johns Hopkins group of medical men
were so deeply interested, in the yellow
fever experiments in Cuba, and, like Dr.
Reed, they sacrificed their lives to sci-
ence.

The pensions are granted, in the lan-
guage of the bill, “in special recognition
of the eminent services of the said James
Carroll and the said Jesse W. Lazear in
discovering the means of preventing as
well as the cause and method of trans-
mission and propagation of yellow fever,
and demonstrating on their own persons
the truth of the theory of the transmis-
sion and propagation of yellow fever in-
fection by mosquitoes,” and in the case
of Dr. Lazear the bill adds these words:
“And the sacrifice of his life in proving
the same.”

As a result of these discoveries it has
been made possible to practically elimi-
nate the scourge of yellow fever.

Dr. Carroll and Dr. Lazear were ap-
pointed to serve under the late Maj.
Walter Reed on the commission to inves-
tigate the yellow fever epidemics in Cuba
in 1900 and 1901. Major Reed was the
head of the commission, but his duties
required him to be in Washington the
greater part of the time, and the actual
work of making the experiments and
demonstrating the truth of the theory
was carried on in Cuba by Major Carroll
and Dr. Lazear.
